The GST Amnesty Scheme was introduced by the government with several key objectives in mind. Primarily, it aimed to provide relief to taxpayers who had not filed their returns on time or had made errors in compliance [6]. This relief was specifically targeted towards those who missed filing GSTR-3B for previous tax periods [4]. Recognizing the challenges and "teething troubles" businesses faced since the inception of GST in July 2017, particularly from FY 2017-18 to FY 2019-20, the scheme aimed to alleviate the burden caused by technical difficulties [7] [15].

One of the main benefits of the scheme is to provide a one-time waiver of late fees, enabling defaulters to file their overdue returns without incurring hefty penalties [15]. The scheme also aimed to reduce the compliance burden on individuals and businesses [10]. By offering extended deadlines, simplified procedures, and financial relief, the GST Amnesty Scheme encourages businesses to settle outstanding dues and ensure smoother compliance [26]. It further supports taxpayers in addressing backlogs [26]. The GST Amnesty Scheme is enacted vide Finance (No. 2) Act 2024 (No. 15 of 2024) dated 16th August 2024 [5].

*   **Restoration of canceled GSTINs:** The amnesty scheme facilitates the restoration of GSTINs for assessees whose GST registrations were canceled [4].

*   **Opportunity to correct errors:** The scheme provides a second chance for taxpayers to correct tax errors without facing severe penalties [13].

The GST Amnesty Scheme, effective from November 1, 2024, also aims to settle outstanding dues and simplify procedures for businesses [9] [15] [21]. Some schemes even address leniently addressing non-filers and zero filers of GST returns to deregister from the GST Council [11] [17].

To benefit from the scheme, the full principal tax demand must be paid [20] [25], and application must be made by June 30, 2025 [3] [20]. The application process for the GST Amnesty Scheme involves several steps and important deadlines. Here's a breakdown:

1.  **Eligibility and Deadlines:**

    *   To qualify for the scheme, taxpayers must fully pay their outstanding principal tax dues by March 31, 2025 [1] [3] [15] [16].
    *   The deadline to apply for the amnesty scheme was June 30, 2025 [3] [15] [28]. Missing either deadline could result in losing the amnesty benefits [3] [15].

2.  **Application Procedure:**

    *   Log in to the GST portal [2] [18] [26] [30].
    *   Navigate to "My Applications" under "Services" and then "User Services" [4] [22] [30].
    *   Select "Apply for Waiver. Scheme under Section 128A" under the "Application Type" dropdown [4] [22].
    *   Eligible individuals can electronically file an application in Form GST SPL-01 on the common portal, including details of the relevant notice or statement [20].
    *   Alternatively, taxpayers can apply for a waiver using form GST SPL-02 [2] [6] [18] [26]. This form is specifically for cases where a demand order or order in appeal has already been passed by tax authorities [32].

3.  **Forms and Documentation:**

    *   Use Form GST APL-01 to file appeals under this scheme, especially if facing GST demand orders under Section 107(1) of the GST Act [5] [33].
    *   Taxpayers must withdraw any pending appeals before applying for the amnesty scheme [10].
    *   Submit necessary documentation via Forms GST SPL-01 or SPL-02 [10].
    *   Table 7 of GST SPL01 provides details regarding the documents required for waiver applications where a demand order or order in appeal has been passed [25].
    *   A screenshot of the appeal withdrawal application may also be required [19].

4.  **Manual Submission (if needed):**

    *   A recent advisory introduced a manual submission option for Section 128A CGST amnesty scheme applicants [17] [29]. This helps taxpayers bypass potential issues with online submission.

5.  **Post-Application:**

    *   You may be able to file an appeal against the GST Amnesty Scheme order issued in SPL 07 form [9].
    *   SPL-03 is relevant within three months of filing SPL-01/02 [14] [28].

The GST Amnesty Scheme aims to provide relief to taxpayers facing difficulties in meeting compliance requirements or dealing with procedural shortcomings [23]. It also assists those whose GST registration was canceled due to the non-filing of tax returns [11] [13].
